ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1-2 (except significantly more during last 2 weeks for final project)
10 hours including modules
I would say about 3 hours per week.
4 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths- great professors, very practical courseImprovements- more clarification about assignments

Strengths: always current - the instructors find a way to make the class relevant and timely to discussions of emergency planning (talking about the olympics and ebola outbreak, etc..). the class is informal which is a nice change from some other settings.weaknesses: not very well aligned with the syllabus; don't necessarily know what to expect when going into class.
Excellent background in emergency preparedness.
The biggest strength is the small class size!Additionally, you gain FEMA course certificates.
strengths: overall introduction of emergency planning

The curriculum is structured properly to allow course topics build upon one another. By the end of the semester we covered a wide variety of emergency situations as well as understanding government structure, response, and third-party efforts. However, I think we could have benefitted from engaging in more interactive presentations where we create drills or exercises and work through these exercises as a class.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Sandy and Joanne both have a strong dynamic that contributes to an interesting class.
Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Very good. Practical knowledge
Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Great instructors. Sandy and Joanne are terrific.
Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  case study is very good

Instructor: Sandy Bogucki  Both Sandy and Joan were wonderful professors. Their personal and professional experience with emergency planning really came through in all of their lectures and discussions. I particularly enjoyed that Joan started off each class withcurrent public health emergency situations (e.g. MERS, ebola outbreak, etc.).

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Craig Michael Rothenberg  craig did a good job of keeping us up-to-date on assignments. not much of a role in the actual classroom
Instructor: Craig Michael Rothenberg  Very good. Helpful with e-mails.
Instructor: Craig Michael Rothenberg  He said two words the entire semester.
Instructor: Craig Michael Rothenberg  Craig is very patient and teaching oriented.

Instructor: Craig Michael Rothenberg  Craig was extremely attentive and afforded great help. It might be more beneficial if he engaged in more class discussions or provided feedback during group projects and individual exercises.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this course as a relatively low stress elective. It can be fun and interesting at times!
Excellent if interested in this topic. Very practical and hands on.
Great course. You gain knowledge from real world first hand experience.
Highly recommend to students who have interest in emergency planning

I would recommend this course for a number of reasons. The course covers the formal structures of emergency preparedness at a government level but it also allows students to critically think through and plan for a number of public health emergency situations. The skills and topics learned in this class can be applied to a number of strategic planning scenarios.
